title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk's killing identified as 22-year-old from Utah, sources say
summary: Officials have identified the person accused of fatally shooting conservative activist Charlie Kirk as 22-year-old Utah resident Tyler Robinson
story: Officials have identified the person accused of fatally shooting conservative activist Charlie Kirk as 22-year-old Utah resident Tyler Robinson.

Utah Governor Spencer Cox said at a press conference on Friday morning that investigators arrested and identified Robinson after analyzing surveillance footage, interviewing Robinson's family members and reviewing online messages between Robinson and his roommate.

"We got him," Cox said, standing with FBI Director Kash Patel and other law enforcement officials. Robinson is expected to be charged with aggravated murder, felony discharge of a firearm causing serious bodily injury and obstruction of justice, according to a probable cause affidavit.
Follow live updates

Kirk, a co-founder of Turning Point USA and an influential voice in the Trump administration, was shot and killed Wednesday during an event at Utah Valley University, a public school south of Salt Lake City. His killing launched a multi-day manhunt among local, state and federal authorities.
The investigation and arrest

Cox said that a family member of Robinson's — Robinson's father, according to two senior law enforcement officials briefed on the investigation — reached out to a family friend who contacted the Washington County Sheriff's Office with information that Robinson had confessed to them or implied that he had committed the incident.
The governor said that investigators interviewed a family member of Robinson's who said he had "become more political in recent years."

"The family member referenced a recent incident in which Robinson came to dinner prior to September 10, and in the conversation with another family member, Robinson mentioned Charlie Kirk was coming to UVU," Cox said. "They talked about why they didn't like him and the viewpoints he had."
Cox said that investigators interviewed Robinson's roommate, who showed authorities messages on Discord between Robinson and his roommate.

The messages associated with the name Tyler state "a need to retrieve a rifle from a drop point, leaving the rifle in a bush," engraving bullets, "having left the rifle wrapped in a towel" and "a mention of a scope and the rifle being unique," Cox said.
Discord confirmed in statement that Robinson had an account on its instant messaging social platform — which has since been taken down — but disputed Cox's characterizations of the messages.

"The messages referenced in recent reporting about planning details do not appear to be Discord messages," the company said. "These were communications between the suspect’s roommate and a friend after the shooting, where the roommate was recounting the contents of a note the suspect had left elsewhere."
Authorities said on Thursday that recovered a "high-powered, bolt-action rifle" in a wooded area just off the of the university campus in conditions that match Robinson's messages.
Cox said the rifle was Mauser 98 .30-06 and had a scope mounted on top of it. He added that inscriptions engraved on casings found with the rifle.

One of the inscriptions had the lyrics to the Italian folk song “Bella Ciao," Cox said. Another read “Hey fascists! Catch!” with an up arrow, a right arrow and three down arrows. A third stated, "If you read this, you are gay LMAO.”
According to Cox, the inscription on the casing fired said: “notices, bulges, OWO, what’s this?”

The governor added that investigators also identified Robinson in surveillance from the Utah Valley University — where Kirk was killed on Wednesday — which showed him arriving to UVU at 8:29 a.m. in a gray Dodge Challenger.

When investigators approached Robinson Thursday, he "was observed in consistent clothing with those surveillance images," Cox said. Surveillance images released by the FBI on Thursday show what appears to be a young, thin man wearing a black long sleeved T-shirt with an American flag on it, black sunglasses, an Adidas hat, jeans and converse sneakers.
NBC News’ searches of state and national public records associated with Robinson’s name and date of birth found no indication of the 22 year old having a prior criminal record.
Public records indicate that Robinson's last voter registration date was on July 13, 2021, and his political party is none declared.
Robinson went to Utah State University for one semester in 2021, a spokesperson for the university confirmed to NBC News.

Kristin Schwiermann, 66, is one of Robinson's neighbors, worked as a custodian at his elementary school and knew him and his family from church. She described him as being "very considerate," "quiet" and "respectful."
"He was a good kid," she said.
Trump announced arrest on Fox News
President Donald Trump, who announced Kirk’s death on Wednesday, was again the first to share that the suspect in Kirk's slaying was in custody on Friday morning.

"I think, with a high degree of certainty, we have him — in custody ... everyone did a great job we worked with the local police, the governor, everybody did a great job,” he said in an interview on Fox News.
Trump suggested that the suspect's father turned him into authorities.

"Somebody that's close recognizes even a little tilt of the head, which nobody else would do," Trump said "And somebody that was very close to him said 'hm, that's him' and essentially went to the father, went to a U.S. Marshal."
"And the father convinced the son, 'this is it,'" Trump added.
Trump repeatedly warned throughout the interview that his information was preliminary, saying he is "always subject to be corrected."
The latest example of political violence

Kirk's killing has prompted national outrage in recent days and renewed fears over political violence in the United States. The shooting was the latest in a series of attacks and threats targeting U.S. political figures of both parties, including President Donald Trump, Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro and Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.

"This is certainly about the the tragic death, assassination, political assassination of Charlie Kirk," Cox, a Republican, said. "But it is also much bigger than an attack on an individual. It is an attack on all of us. It is an attack on the American experiment. It is an attack on our ideals."
Turning Point USA has not publicly commented on the arrest or the identification of the suspect.

In a statement on Thursday, Turning Point USA said Kirk had faced "thousands" of threats throughout his life but “always prioritized reaching as many young Americans as possible over his own personal safety.”
"All of us will miss Charlie," the group said. "None of us will ever forget him.”

title: Charlie Kirk was spreading his conservative message in Asia days before he was killed
summary: Just days before he was killed, Charlie Kirk was in Asia spreading his conservative and anti-immigration message, making stops in South Korea and Japan, where he urged people to have more children and embrace religion.
story: HONG KONG — Less than a week before he was killed, Charlie Kirk was in Asia spreading his conservative and anti-immigration message, making stops in South Korea and Japan, where he urged people to have more children and embrace religion.

“Their country is totally under attack,” he said of South Korea on his podcast this week after returning from his trip. “The same things that we have been fighting for here, whether it be lawfare in South Korea or mass migration in Japan — this is a worldwide phenomenon.”

There is a receptive audience for messages such as Kirk’s in South Korea and Japan, both East Asian democracies and U.S. allies with highly monoethnic populations, falling birth rates and growing far-right movements.

Anti-feminist backlash in South Korea, which ranks 101st out of 148 countries in the World Economic Forum’s latest Global Gender Gap Report, was said to play a role in the 2022 presidential election victory of Yoon Suk Yeol. As Yoon faced impeachment over his December 2024 declaration of martial law, supporters who embraced his claims of election fraud and legal persecution adopted symbols and slogans associated with President Donald Trump.

In Japan, government efforts to bring in more foreign labor in the face of an aging population have met with resistance, and last month there was public panic when misinformation about a new cultural exchange program suggested it would lead to a flood of immigrants from four countries in Africa.

Kirk’s first stop was in Seoul, where last Friday and Saturday he spoke at Build Up Korea, a conservative forum previously attended by Donald Trump Jr. and whose advisory board includes President Trump’s adviser Alex Bruesewitz and Steve Bannon’s daughter Maureen Bannon.
“The phenomenon of young people, especially men, turning conservative is occurring simultaneously across multiple continents,” said Kirk, 31, according to the South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo.

“It is not unique to the U.S., which is why it deserves more attention. That is why I chose South Korea as my first Asian destination,” said Kirk, a co-founder of Turning Point USA, a nonprofit group that promotes conservative political ideals to young people.
More on Charlie Kirk's assassination

Kirk was welcomed with pyrotechnics and chants of “USA” as he walked onto the stage and spoke against immigration, communism, and cheered the prevalence of Christianity in South Korea.
He also pointed out how safe he had felt walking around the South Korean capital, which he later recalled in his podcast as “striking” and “amazing.”
“I didn’t even have to think about where I was going because anywhere I went I knew it would be perfectly clean and safe,” he told the forum attendees. “A lot of American cities are not like that.”

title: A person is killed and an ICE agent injured in an immigration arrest near Chicago
summary: A spokesperson for Immigration and Customs Enforcement said officers were conducting a vehicle stop as part of their "targeted law enforcement activity" on Friday morning.
story: An officer fatally shot a person who injured an ICE agent during an immigration arrest in the Chicago area Friday, according to federal immigration officials.
A spokesperson for Immigration and Customs Enforcement said  that officers were conducting a vehicle stop as part of a "targeted law enforcement activity" on Friday morning.

The person being stopped resisted and attempted to drive his vehicle into the officers arresting him, subsequently striking and dragging one of them, ICE said in a statement. "Fearing for his life, the officer discharged his firearm and struck the subject," ICE said.
Photos and video captured by NBC Chicago showed multiple law enforcement vehicles in Franklin Park, where the shooting occurred.
Both the officer and the driver were taken to a hospital. The driver was pronounced dead at the hospital. The officer sustained severe injuries and is in stable condition, ICE said.

“We are praying for the speedy recovery of our law enforcement officer," Homeland Security Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin said in a statement. "He followed his training, used appropriate force, and properly enforced the law to protect the public and law enforcement."

​The Department of Homeland Security identified the driver who was killed as Silverio Villegas-Gonzalez. DHS said in a statement that he was the "target of the enforcement operation" and that he came to the United States "at an unknown date and time."
DHS accused Villegas-Gonzalez of having "a history of reckless driving."
The Federal Bureau of Investigations said it was assisting law enforcement officers in response to the incident, NBC Chicago reported.
Democratic Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois said in a social media post that he is “aware of the troubling incident that has unfolded in Franklin Park.”
“This is a developing situation and the people of Illinois deserve a full, factual accounting of what’s happened today to ensure transparency and accountability,” Pritzker said.

Villegas-Gonzalez's death comes on the same week ICE launched its immigration enforcement campaign “Operation Midway Blitz" across the state of Illinois, particularly focusing on Chicago. It was not immediately clear if the enforcement activity that led up to the shooting was part of the campaign.

As part of the campaign, hundreds of ICE agents were expected to use the Great Lakes Naval Base in North Chicago for staging, and a federal immigration facility in suburban Broadview for processing, NBC Chicago reported.

title: Cooper Hoffman Reveals the Physical Demands of Filming 'The Long Walk'
summary: Cooper Hoffman stars in the on-screen adaptation of Stephen King's "The Long Walk" and revealed the physical toll of filming.
story: For actor Cooper Hoffman, his latest project has proven to be his most physically demanding role yet.
Starring as Raymond Garraty in the new movie “The Long Walk,” Hoffman plays a teenager forced to participate in a grueling walking competition where both the stakes and casualties are high.

Based off of the 1979 Stephen King novel, which was penned under the pseudonym Richard Bachman, the dystopian thriller tells the story of 50 boys who must walk great lengths in order to survive a totalitarian regime. If a walker fails to maintain a specific pace, the consequences are deadly.
In an interview with TODAY.com, Hoffman provided a glimpse at the physical demands of the outdoor set, sans shade.
“I think we walked around 15 miles per day, on concrete” Hoffman says. “We ended up walking close to 400 miles total — it was crazy.”

“We all got really excited for this thing that will never be made again and we all wanted to be a part of it. But when we got there and started walking, there was a real anxiety to making it through the day," he adds.
For Hoffman, the role is a decidedly dark departure from his previous work, which includes supporting roles in "Saturday Night" and the Golden Globe-nominated 2021 film, "Licorice Pizza."

“It's completely different from any coming-of-age movie I've ever done,” says Hoffman, who's set to appear in Luca Guadagnino's upcoming movie “Artificial.” “Honestly, I hope to do different things every time I do a movie."
As the son of the late Oscar-winning actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, he said he recognizes the pressure in pursuing a career in Hollywood.

“We have an Oscar at the house, and that's not something everyone can say. It's something that's kind of looking at you your whole life, and you don't want to step into something and not do it as well as that person did,” Hoffman said on TODAY Sept. 5.

“But then I did ‘Licorice Pizza’ and I kept doing movies, and I realized that this is where I want to be right now," he added. "It might not be where I want to be for the rest of my life, but who knows? I'll do it until I don't want to do it anymore.”
“The Long Walk” hit theaters Friday, Sept. 12.

title: ‘Love Boat’ Reunion! See What Brought the Stars of the Classic Show Together
summary: Stars from "The Love Boat" reunited for the premiere of a new play, written by star Ted Lange and starring Fred Grandy and Jill Whelan.
story: Come aboard, we’re expecting you ... to love this reunion.
Four stars from “The Love Boat” appeared at the premiere of the off-Broadway play “Lady Patriot,” written and directed by Ted Lange, who played Isaac the bartender on the classic ABC series.

Lange was joined at the Sept. 9 premiere by Fred Grandy, who played Gopher; Bernie Kopell, who played Doc; and Jill Whelan, who portrayed Vicki, the daughter of the late Gavin MacLeod's Captain Stubing.
Whelan and Grandy star in the play, based on the true story of a formerly enslaved Black woman working undercover as a spy for the Union during the Civil War.
Whelan said her history with Lange and Grandy helped calm any anxiety she had about doing the play before it opened.

“I would normally say, ‘Absolutely,’ and I do have some semblance of it,” Whelan said while appearing with Lange and Grandy on New York’s WPIX on Sept. 10. “But because I love these two gentlemen so much, and we have such a shorthand together, there’s a level of trust with us that just eliminates any of that because I know they have my back, I have their back.”
MacLeod died in 2021 but he is also very much a part of the play, his former co-stars said.

“In the play, obviously we’re wearing period costumes, and I decided to wear a pair of earrings that I have that are perfect for the period in the 1860s,” Whelan said. “Gavin MacLeod bought them for me. I thought, what a perfect homage to him.”
“He was very much the spiritual leader of the show,” Grandy said.
“He was a wonderful man,” Lange added.
“The Love Boat” aired for 10 seasons from 1977 until 1987.
“Lady Patriot” has a limited run, only showing until Sept. 20.

title: 'Hunting Wives' Renewed for Season 2 — and Its Stars Made a Deliciously Dramatic Video to Celebrate
summary: "The Hunting Wives" has been renewed for a second season by Netflix. Stars Malin Akerman and Brittany Snow helped announce the news in a video.
story: "The Hunting Wives" is returning to Netflix for another season of Southern-fried secrets, sex and murder.

Malin Åkerman and Brittany Snow announced the hit drama was renewed for a second season in a hilarious social media video Sept. 12 that tapped into the deliciously twisted vibe between their characters, alluring Texas socialite and girl group leader Margo (Åkerman) and Sophie, the wide-eyed Yankee transplant whose life goes awry after she falls under Margo's spell (Snow).
The clip kicks off with Snow, looking raccoonish thanks to smeared mascara, ranting into her phone as she records a video message for Åkerman.

"Do you think if you ignore me I'm just going to go away? How dare you? I lost everything because of you! You magnetic, charismatic, perfectly symmetrical, beautiful —" Snow says before Åkerman appears on screen wrapped in a towel as she steps out of the shower.
"Hi, honey," the Swedish-born actor coos soothingly to her co-star, who now cowers nervously out of camera in embarrassment.
"You know I know what you sound like when you breathe on the phone," Åkerman tells her.
"That's unfortunate," Snow mumbles.
"Are you OK?" Åkerman asks.
Snow begins rambling, telling her co-star, "I would give anything to see you. I would give up my dignity. I would give up my morals."

Åkerman, channeling the manipulative Margo, reassures her, "It's just you and me, remember? I have a feeling we're going to see each other real soon. Actually, I know we're going to see each other really soon."
A beat later, Åkerman is wearing a Margo-like red wig to announce in a Texas drawl, "Pack your boots and load your guns. We're going back to Maple Brook for Season 2, baby!"
Netflix also shared the news on its Tudum website, noting that Season 1 of the fan-favorite series, which is based on May Cobb's 2021 novel of the same name, "ended with body bags aplenty."

"Sophie and Margo are on the outs. But soon enough, old secrets and new foes force them back together. As they play their dangerous games, the question arises: Are they the hunters or the hunted?” Netflix asked ahead of Season 2.

Executive producer Rebecca Cutter said in a statement, “I’m so excited to write these amazing characters again. And I can’t wait to take the audience on another sexy, twisted, bats--- crazy ride through Maple Brook.”
Season 1 cast members joining Åkerman and Snow when the series returns include Jaime Ray Newman (Callie), Evan Jonigkeit (Graham) and George Ferrier (Brad).

title: Dunkin' Is Giving Away Sabrina Carpenter Cups: How to Get Yours
summary: Dunkin’ is giving out free reusable Sabrina Carpenter cups at its stores Friday, Sept. 12. Here's how to get one.
story: Dunkin’ is doling out freebies this weekend, and you don’t even have to say “Please Please Please” to get ‘em.
On Sept. 12 — that’s today, if you didn’t know — Dunkin’ is handing out free, reusable “Sabrina Cups” offered with the purchase of any Daydream Refresher while supplies last.

“It’s everything,” Dunkin' wrote on an Instagram post alongside heart-eyes emoji, showing the orange-and-pink gradient tumbler finished with stars and a lipstick kiss reminiscent of Carpenter's “Short n’ Sweet” album cover. The chain says that limited quantities are available and encourages fans to “get yours while you can.”

It should be noted that multiple customers commented on the Dunkin' post saying that certain restaurants didn’t have the cup when they visited. I called my local Dunkin’ in the Washington, D.C., area and it had the cup, so giving your local spot a ring before you go couldn’t hurt.
Which Daydream Refreshers Are on the Dunkin’ Menu?
Currently, Dunkin’ offers three Sabrina Carpenter Daydream Refreshers:

Sabrina’s Strawberry Daydream Refresher: It's made with “sweet strawberry flavor” and oat milk, then topped with cold foam.Sabrina’s Mango Daydream Refresher: Described as “tropical and bright” by the chain, this also is crafted with oat milk and then topped with cold foam.Sabrina’s Mixed Berry Daydream Refresher: This new refresher joined the menu in August along with the chain’s fall menu, and is made with oat milk and topped with cold foam.
Sabrina’s Strawberry Daydream Refresher: It's made with “sweet strawberry flavor” and oat milk, then topped with cold foam.
Sabrina’s Mango Daydream Refresher: Described as “tropical and bright” by the chain, this also is crafted with oat milk and then topped with cold foam.
Sabrina’s Mixed Berry Daydream Refresher: This new refresher joined the menu in August along with the chain’s fall menu, and is made with oat milk and topped with cold foam.
Customers can also order a “Mix Your Own Refresher” with customizable bases — green tea, black tea, lemonade, sparkling water, water or oat milk — and sweetness levels.
Sabrina Carpenter’s History with Dunkin’

Carpenter has been fostering a Ben Affleck-level relationship with Dunkin’ for a little while now: Sabrina’s Brown Sugar Shakin’ Espresso debuted in December 2024 along with the chain's winter menu and proved a popular drink to try on social media.

Since then, the partnership between the singer-songwriter and doughnut chain has led to a lot: a second drink (the Strawberry Daydream Refresher) in June, the Mango and Mixed Berry Refreshers after that, and various commercials and pop culture moments.
Earlier this month, Carpenter debuted an ad for the Dunkin’ Daydream Hotline at the 2025 MTV Video Music Awards that offered free drinks to fans who called in.

The Grammy winner has previously found fans of her Dunkin’ drinks — and new fans of her own — in places far from an award stage: In January, an 81-year-old in Raleigh, North Carolina, who goes by “Grandma C” on TikTok reviewed Carpenter’s Brown Sugar Shakin’ Espresso even though she had no idea who the singer was.
After uploading the positive review and going viral, "Grandma C" received a comment from Carpenter herself, who wrote, “i love you grandma C 💋.” The TikToker replied, “I love you❤️❤️.”

title: Inside Kristen Bell and Dax Shepard's Relationship
summary: When did Kristen Bell and Dax Shepard meet, start dating and get married? How many kids do they have? Here are their daughters' names, ages and their love story.
story: Kristen Bell and Dax Shepard are proof that finding the perfect partner doesn’t mean finding the perfect match.
In fact, according to the 45-year-old “Frozen” star, she and her 50-year-old husband are more of a mismatch, in the best possible way.

“I married my polar opposite,” she once told E! News. “We are the antithesis of each other. We argue about absolutely everything, but there is a foundational trust that we’ve built that keeps us together and is quite stimulated by one another’s opinions.”
Take a look back at how the devoted couple came together in this timeline of their union, from first meeting to building a family together.
2007: How They Met and Started Dating
Bell and Shepard first met at the birthday party of their mutual friend, producer Shauna Robertson, but according to Bell, there weren’t “any sparks” at first.

"The only thing I remember is that he talked so much," she said on TODAY in 2019. "There were no sparks whatsoever." (Shepard went on to become a successful podcast host, with his "Armchair Expert" empire).
Bell recalled that it wasn’t until two weeks later, when she bumped into him at a hockey game. They bonded over being Red Wings fans from Detroit and "started to flirt," she said on TODAY.
He made a big impression when he reached out to her the next day.

“Truly, his first text to me was: ‘Hi. My name is Dax. I violated your privacy and got your number from Shauna. How do you feel about that?’” Bell noted. “And I was like, 'Excuse me? You sound stimulating.'"
"He's so bold. That's my kind of person," she said.
From there the pair started dating — briefly.
2007: How They Split (and Got Back Together)
In the early days of their relationship, the stars weren’t exactly on the same page when it came to their feelings for each other.

“We were dating for about three months, and I already knew that I was in love with him,” Bell mentioned in an interview with PopSugar. “And he was hesitant, because he knew he was still dating other people.”
Shepard decided the best thing to do would be to end it before things went any further.

“He sat me down and said, ‘I can’t have this right now. I think you’re wonderful, but I am still dating other people,’” Bell recalled. “And then I, like, liquefied and fell to the ground, but I felt incredibly respected that he had the balls to tell me we weren’t in the same place.”

And that’s where their story would have ended, if Shepard hadn’t quickly realized his mistake. It only took him four days to stop dating anyone else and commit himself to a future with Bell. It’s a point she likes to “remind him of” from time to time.
2009: From Partners to Co-Stars
The actors decided to mix business and pleasure in 2009 by traveling to Italy and starring alongside one another in the rom-com “When in Rome,” which hit theaters the following year.

That was just the first time Bell and Shepard joined forces on the big screen. They did it again for 2012’s “Hit and Run,” which was written and directed by Shepard, the 2014 “Veronica Mars” feature and once more for the 2017 action-comedy “Chips.” In 2018 Shepard made a one-off appearance on Bell’s small screen hit, “The Good Place.”
2010: Engagement News

In February 2010, hot off the heels of the release of “When in Rome,” the couple hit the red carpet at the 52nd Annual Grammy Awards, where one part of Bell’s wardrobe served as a major announcement: a sparkling ring on that finger.
Bell’s rep confirmed the happy news, stating, “Yes, they are engaged.”
The couple had a long engagement, choosing to wait until LGBTQ+ marriage was legal in California to get married themselves.

Bell said in a 2012 interview with The Advocate, "I don’t feel appropriate taking advantage of a right that’s denied to my best friends. That’s why we’ve been so hesitant. Dax and I have talked about it a lot, and this issue is very important to both of us. We’re just standing up for what we believe in. Period.”

Shepard said something similar on Morning Joe: “We don’t want to have a ceremony that other people can’t have.” They were waiting until the day "all of our friends in California can also get married."
March 2013: Welcoming Their 1st Child

Given that they wanted to hold off on the nuptials until same-sex marriage was legal in their home state of California, it proved to be a long engagement for Shepard and Bell. In fact, before they had a chance to become husband and wife, they became mom and dad.
In March 2013, the couple celebrated the arrival of their first child, a baby girl.
October 2013: Wedding Bells

During the summer of 2013, California’s Proposition 8 was repealed, thus allowing same-sex couples to wed. Just three months after that, Bell and Shepard decided to take their long-awaited walk down the aisle.
They said their “I dos” at the Beverly Hills County Clerk’s Office.
“We drove to the courthouse,” Bell recalled during a 2022 visit to TODAY. “And I thought we were just going to go as is.”
But Shepard had another idea.
“I came out in sweatpants, and my husband was in a tuxedo, which was so cute, and he was like, I’ll go pick your outfit out,” she recalled. “And he picked out a little black jumpsuit.”

As for the cake, the couple’s friends, who weren’t invited to the nuptials, brought them one with an iced message that playfully summed up their own sentiments about the big day. It read, “The World’s Worst Wedding.”
The cost of the entire event was just $147, Bell said.
December 2014: It’s a Girl — Again!
The couple welcomed their second child, daughter Delta Bell Shepard, on Dec. 19, 2014, even though they never thought two kids were in the cards for them.
“We did not want a second child,” Shepard later revealed on an episode of “The Endless Honeymoon Podcast.”
But it was the reality of busy life with their firstborn that convinced them they needed to expand their family.
“It’s not fair to bring this little human everywhere we go and deal with only adults,” the “Parenthood” alum said of Delta’s big sister. “We owe it to her to give her a playmate.”

And they felt they owed both of their children something else — privacy. Earlier in 2014, Shepard and Bell launched a social media campaign with the hashtag #NoKidsPolicy, devoted to urging others to boycott publications that purchase paparazzi photos of celebrities’ children.

“We think that people who like looking at children in magazines must actually like children,” Shepard wrote in a 2014 essay for HuffPost. “We are betting on the chance that they like them enough to protect them from constantly being shadowed by strange men (not trying to be sexist — I’m sure there are plenty of strange women in the ‘razzi game).”
2021: They Share a Smelly Parenting Hack

When should a parent let a fussy kid go to bed without a bath, and when should they convince their little ones to take the plunge? Bell and Shepard visited TODAY in 2021 and revealed how they decide when it’s worth the bath-time battle.
“It’s a smell test,” Bell said. “It’s a foot smell test. And then you just pop them in the water or the shower or the bath.”
Shepard added that he and Bell are particularly laidback about the matter in the summer.
“You’re just bathing them far less,” he said of the warmer season. “You’re kind of leaving them in charge of it, which they’re bad at it. Then a whiff will hit you and you go, ‘Oh, it’s time!’”
2025: A Celebration of Sobriety
Shepard has been an open book when it comes to the topic of his battle with addition and path to recovery.
But these days his love is fully focused on his wife and children, and the former took to Instagram on Sept. 4, 2025 to celebrate a milestone in Shepard’s sobriety.

“This is what 21 years of sobriety looks like,” Bell wrote alongside a carousel of sweet family photos. “Lots of hugging. Hugging everyone and everything. Hugging life. Thank you for getting sober, @daxshepard. I am eternally grateful to have you. We all are.”

title: Ego Nwodim Announces She’s Leaving ‘Saturday Night Live’ After 7 Seasons
summary: Ego Nwodim has announced she will be leaving “Saturday Night Live” less than a month before the premiere of its 51st season.
story: Another longtime "Saturday Night Live" cast member is leaving the show after its landmark 50th season, marking the latest cast change before the show returns in October.
Ego Nwodim has announced she is leaving the sketch comedy staple.
“The hardest part of a great party is knowing when to say goodnight. But after seven unforgettable seasons, I have decided to leave ‘SNL,’” she wrote Sept. 12 on her Instagram stories.
Nwodim went on to thank show creator Lorne Michaels, as well as the show’s cast and crew.

“I am immensely grateful to Lorne for the opportunity, to my castmates, the writers, and the crew for their brilliance, support, and friendship,” she wrote. “Week after week on that stage taught me more than I could have ever imagined, and I will carry those memories (and that laughter) with me always.”
Nwodim, who joined “SNL” in 2018 before its 44th season, went viral in 2023 for her “Lisa from Temecula” sketch and got the studio audience to shout an expletive earlier this year.
She previously opened up about her desire to elevate her career, while acknowledging how amazing it was to be part of “SNL.”
“Dream come true. I want my other dreams to come true. I want to be in films and I want to do more TV as well,” she told Deadline  in 2023.
Nwodim is the latest star to exit the series.
TODAY.com learned in August that Heidi Gardner will not return after eight seasons. She has yet to make a statement about her departure.
Michael Longfellow, Devon Walker and Emil Wakim also confirmed they would not be returning to the show.
The departures come on the heels of Michaels promising to “shake things up” in an interview with Puck News.

“I wanted people coming back and being part of (the 50th season),” he said. “And that meant there couldn’t be those kind of disruptions (to the cast), or anything that was going to take the focus off (the 50th season).”

While multiple stars will be leaving “SNL,” the show will add five new cast members, including Tommy Brennan, Jeremy Culhane, Ben Marshall, Kam Patterson and Veronika Slowikowska. Veterans Colin Jost and Michael Che will return to “Weekend Update,” while Bowen Yang, Kenan Thompson, Marcello Hernandez, Chloe Fineman and more are set to return.
Season 51 of “Saturday Night Live” will premiere Oct. 4 on NBC.

title: 'The Girlfriend' Ending: Who Dies and Does Daniel Pick Laura or Cherry?
summary: Is Laura dead in The Girlfriend? What happens to Cherry and Daniel? Robin Wright explains his character's fate.
story: Warning: This post contains spoilers for “The Girlfriend.”
Nobody could have seen the twist in the last episode of “The Girlfriend” coming — except Robin Wright.
In an interview with TODAY.com, the show’s star and director reveals that she, in fact, came up with the twist. “It’s more of a surprise,” she says with a smile.

"The Girlfriend" is based on a novel of the same name by Michelle Frances and follows the two most important women in an aspiring young doctor's life: His protective mother, Laura (Wright), and his new girlfriend, Cherry (Olivia Cooke).

The series takes alternating viewpoints to unspool the story. Laura is suspicious of Cherry, fearing she's more attracted to the family's wealth than to her son, Daniel (Laurie Davidson) — and soon, fearing Cherry herself.
Cherry, in Laura, sees an adversary and an obstacle to her ultimate happy ending and ladder up from her lower class upbringing.
How does this tale end? Find out.
How Does 'The Girlfriend' End?

Laura and Cherry's battle for Daniel goes from passive aggressive to straight-up aggressive as the show unspools. Cherry tries to paint Laura as crazy; Laura tries to prove that Cherry is the crazy one, but is losing credibility.

Then, Laura makes a drastic decision that changes the course of the show, and her son's life. After an accident during a weekend getaway with Cherry, Daniel falls into a coma. Laura sees his injury as an opening to get rid of Cherry. She tells Cherry that Daniel has died — but he hasn't. Eventually, Cherry and Daniel figure out the betrayal and reunite.

Still, even after Daniel shuts her out of his life, Laura is desperate to show him who his girlfriend really is. Laura speaks to Cherry's mom and learns all about her past, including the lengths she's willing to go to get what she wants. Cherry's mom paints her as a dangerous figure.

Laura visits Daniel and drugs his drink. All she needs is a moment to play the recording, she says. That, of course, is not what happens. Cherry bursts in and Laura, now desperate herself, chases her around the mansion. It culminates in a showdown in the London home's pool, where Cherry and Laura try to drown each other.
More from 'The Girlfriend'
Do Cherry and Daniel End Up Together in ‘The Girlfriend’?
Do Cherry and Daniel End Up Together in ‘The Girlfriend’?
Then, Daniel wakes up from his valium-induced stupor and finishes the job for Cherry.
"He drowns her in the pool," Wright says.
Wright says the twist came during early discussions for "The Girlfriend" and how it would compare to the book.

"Initially, everybody thought, 'Well, this is going to be a no-brainer. Cherry kills Laura, then she wins. And I was like, 'No, let my baby kill me,'" Wright says, calling it a twist out of a Greek tragedy.
Wright says Laura's decisions are controversial, but Laura's impulse to find fault with her son's partner is relatable.
"It's always going to be that way (with kids' partners). Not to that degree. But it'll be like, 'Oh, I don't like the way she puts her hands in her pocket,'" she says.
In this case, though, Laura's worst fears of her son's girlfriend were likely real — she would do anything to get what she wanted.
Is Laura Really Dead in 'The Girlfriend'?
"She could still be alive," Wright says. "If he resuscitates her, that's not on camera."
Wright says the ending is "open-ended" in the sense of Laura's fate. When asked, straight-up, if she's alive, Wright responds, "We'll see."

When it comes to Daniel, his future and next move are also up in the air. The series ends at a gathering with Daniel, his father and Cherry, now pregnant. Daniel finds the phone that his mother had used to record Cherry's mom's confession, then watches it.
All these months later, Cherry's secrets are out. On Daniel's face is a pained look: He killed his mother and now he's stuck with the woman who led him to that point.
"I said, 'If you guys want to do a Season 2, it should be called 'The Boyfriend.' And he kills her," Wright jokes.
What's Next for Cherry and Daniel?
Laurie Davidson said, in an interview with TODAY.com, that he believes his character is at the start of a new journey.
“Daniel would go looking for some answers from Cherry. You know, he’s killed his mom to protect who he loved,” he tells TODAY.com.
“He’s going to need a lot of therapy,” he says.

title: See Craig Melvin Help the Harlem Globetrotters Break a Guinness World Record
summary: TODAY's Craig Melvin stepped in to help the Harlem Globetrotters break a Guinness World Record live on air
story: TODAY's Craig Melvin stepped in to help the Harlem Globetrotters break a Guinness World Record live on air!
Craig joined the legendary basketball team as they attempted to break the record for longest relay passing a spinning basketball with one continuous spin on the TODAY Plaza on Sept. 12.
To break the record, the Globetrotters needed to pass a spinning basketball on their finger from one player to another, with a minimum of six people.
Guinness World Records adjudicator Michael Empric joined the team on the plaza and went over the rules for the attempt.

"So the Globetrotters are attempting to break the Guinness World Records title for longest relay passing a spinning basketball," Empric said. "The mark to beat is six. I need one single spin, clean transfers from person to person, and if the ball falls off, the attempt ends."
The seven Globetrotters grabbed their ball celebrating 100 years of the team, and got spinning.
"I'm gonna try to get you guys a good spin first," Globetrotter Thunder Law said. "Let's do it!"
The Globetrotters hit six on their first attempt, before the ball spun off of a player's finger.
"We got the record now, y'all saw it, but we want to do it with swag," Law said as he regrouped the players. "Come on!"
Each of the seven players then spun the basketball on their finger, before passing it to Craig, which made the crowd on the plaza to burst into cheers.

"So the mark to beat was six," Empric said. "The first attempt you hit six, the second attempt you hit eight! It's a new Guinness World Record. Congratulations, Globetrotters, you are officially amazing."
Empric added: "And Craig, congratulations!"
Craig ran over to the team to celebrate, including jumping up and down, screaming and joining a team high-five.
"100 years of excellence right there, baby," Law said as his teammate held up their new world record plaque.

The Globetrotters, an exhibition basketball team, are gearing up to celebrate their centennial anniversary in 2026, and in honor, the team will be traveling to more than 300 cities across the world next year.
The team is kicking off their world tour on Dec. 14 in their hometown arena of Madison Square Garden, before heading to 200 cities in the U.S. and more than 100 more across the globe.
"One thing about the Globetrotters, we go all over the world every year," Law said. "We've been doing it for 100 years now, which is crazy."
"That's the beautiful thing about the Globetrotters — if you can't catch us here in New York, just check harlemglobetrotters.com and we will be somewhere near you," he added.

title: Al Roker Shares a Cute Moment With Jonathan Groff at Broadway Show — Watch the Video
summary: Jonathan Groff sang and danced alongside Al Roker in the middle of his "Just in Time" performance on Broadway.
story: Al Roker had quite the experience when he went to Jonathan Groff's Broadway musical "Just in Time."

While performing Bobby Darin’s hit song “Just in Time” at the Sept. 11 show, Groff went into the audience and started singing to Al, who was smiling from ear to ear. When Groff approached him, Al got out of his chair and held Groff's hand as the "Glee" star twirled him around and gave him a kiss on the hand.
The whole moment was captured on camera and later shared on the official social media accounts for the Broadway musical.
The caption read, "Look who came to dance TODAY 🥹 thanks for coming to #JustInTimeBway @alroker."
Fans were living for the moment.
One person commented, "Love this so much!!!"
Another wrote, "Best show ever!!! Love Jonathon Groff!!"
A third added, "I could watch this over and over."

"Just in Time" is based on the life and times of legendary singer Bobby Darin, who is known for songs like “Splish Splash,” “Dream Lover,” “Mack the Knife” and more. In the show, Groff plays the late icon, who died at 37 in 1973 after undergoing open-heart surgery.
Groff's role as Darin earned him a Tony nomination for best performance by an actor in a leading role in a musical.
On the 3rd Hour of TODAY Sept. 12, Groff talked a little about his role in the musical and said it's been "incredible" portraying the star onstage.

"I knew the songs 'Dream Lover,' 'Mack the Knife,' 'Splish Splash,' 'Beyond the Sea,' 'If I Were a Carpenter' — I didn't necessarily know they were all sung by the same person. He's a real unsung hero," Groff said. "He was swapping genres before 'Cowboy Carter.' He was really ahead of his time."

Groff then talked about the fun moment when he went into the audience to sing to Al. Since "Just in Time" opened on Broadway in April, Groff has made a habit out of singing to audience members during the show.
He said he does this as an homage to Darin, who was "famous for connecting with his audiences more than anyone."
"He would pick up people to dance," he said.
As for how the audience reacted to Al, Groff said he's never seen that before.

"I'm telling you, the audience has not gone crazier for anyone else in the six months that we've been doing this show," he told Al on the 3rd Hour of TODAY. "The audience lit up so much when you came and stood and gave that twirl. It was incredible. You're beloved!"
Groff also talked about his performance as Darin in an April interview with Vogue. The "Frozen" star revealed why he tends to go in and out of character during the show.

“I knew I wanted to start the show as myself, and break the fourth wall with the audience to create that connection that Bobby was really famous for — the vibe that we’re all here today, in this present moment, and anything can happen,” he said. “I’m trying to evoke this real love affair between performer and audience, and that’s where the conceit of the show came from and continues to live.”

title: 'Downton' Actor Says Final Movie Made Audience 'Suddenly Crumble': 'An Amazing Thing to Watch'
summary: After more than 15 years, "Downton Abbey" is coming to an end. Cast members Hugh Bonneville, Allen Leech and Kevin Doyle reveal if fans can expect a sequel.
story: After more than 15 years, the cast of "Downton Abbey" is making its final curtain call in the movie "Downton Abbey: The Grand Finale," the last installment in the period drama.
The long-running series has provided a glimpse into the early 20th century world of the Crawley family and their servants, all residing in an English castle called Downton Abbey.

The latest film bids adieu to both the series and its beloved characters including Lord Grantham (Hugh Bonneville), Lady Grantham (Elizabeth McGovern), Lady Mary Talbot (Michelle Dockery), Lady Edith Hexham (Laura Carmichael), Mr. Carson (Jim Carter), Anna Bates (Joanne Froggatt), Tom Branson (Allen Leech), Mr. Molesley (Kevin Doyle) and the Dowager Countess, played by Maggie Smith, who notably died in 2024, among other members of the Grantham family and staff.

Ahead of the final film, TODAY.com sat down with Bonneville, Leech and Doyle to find out how they feel about leaving Downton behind, the movie's emotional ending and whether or not fans can expect another sequel.
Beyond the Abbey
The series may be over, but in the hearts of fans, their favorite characters will live on indefinitely.
“I like the idea of the audience using their imagination and imagining how those characters are going to develop over the years,” Doyle says.
“(We) leave it to them now,” he continues.
Even so, that doesn’t stop the trio from speculating on what could happen to their respective characters, starting with Mr. Moseley, the servant turned successful screenwriter.
Moseley will “one day give an Oscar speech,” Leech predicts, before pondering Tom Branson’s possible fate, which is to continue establishing himself and his future legacy as a business mogul.
“(Tom’s) very much found his place in society, in the world. He’s very comfortable now and I think I like that idea,” says Leech.

In “The Grand Finale,” Bonneville’s character, Robert Crawley, must come to terms with embracing a new chapter and, according to Bonneville, it’s not unlike his own bittersweet goodbye to the franchise.
"It's a chapter that I think — I speak for all of us — that we'll never forget. It's been an extraordinary experience that none of us predicted and it is a once-in-a-career experience," he says.
"It's a testament to the cast and the audience that we've sustained it for so long. So, I'm walking off into the sunset with great pride and fond memories."
That ‘Gut-Punch’ Ending
In “The Grand Finale,” the Crawley family's epic saga reaches its conclusion and with it comes its share of heart-wrenching moments, which even the cast found themselves getting emotional over.
“I had to reach for Michelle’s (Dockery) hand in the dark as we were watching in the Soho screening room,” Bonneville says.
Leech says that he was also caught off guard by the movie’s final scenes.
“I ran back to the theater last night to watch the last 10 minutes and it really is very emotional,” Leech reveals.

“Because I wasn’t sitting down, I got to watch the audience. And to watch them go from pure elation of being there and immersed in the world of Downton again, and watching them suddenly crumble, I have to say, it kind of (gave me) immense pleasure,” he says with laugh.
“It was great to know that they loved these characters so much that it really was affecting them,” he continues. “It was really an amazing thing to watch.”
For Doyle, “The Grand Finale” didn’t cut as deep as the original ending of the series, saying that there were “a lot of tears” when the show ended in 2015.
“The end of the TV series hit hard because we thought that that was it,” Doyle recalls. “And it had been a glorious six years.”
But as everyone knows, the franchise was far from over.
“We’ve kind of had these bonus goodbyes,” says Leech of the subsequent sequels.
Will ‘Downton Abbey’ Ever Return?

After airing on PBS from 2010 to 2015, the Julian Fellowes show hit the big screen in 2019 with the eponymous movie, “Downton Abbey,” followed by 2022’s “Downton Abbey: A New Era,” and, of course, the final installment, “Downton Abbey: The Grand Finale.”
Is there a chance that Downton could once more make its return?
“The fact is, the castle’s always been the central character, so that’s still there. Put it that way,” says Bonneville. “I mean, it’s just time for us to finish.”
Leech agrees, saying, “Just the story of Downton is probably over for our characters, doesn’t mean the story of Downton (is over) though.”

title: All About Harrison Ford and Calista Flockhart's Relationship
summary: Inside Harrison Ford and Calista Flockhart's relationship timeline. What is their age difference? Who are their kids? When did they get married?
story: When Harrison Ford and Calista Flockhart first got together in the early aughts, some fans were surprised by the match. After all, there were a couple of decades between the veteran film actor and the then-prime time star.
But that didn’t matter to them.
“It doesn’t faze me,” Flockhart told Hello! Magazine in 2003. “Sometimes I even say, ‘Wow, I keep forgetting that he’s 22 years older than me.’ It doesn’t factor into our relationship at all.”
Ford joined her for that same interview and commented, “Romantic love is one of the most exciting and fulfilling kinds of love, and I think there is a potential for it at any stage of your life.”
Years later, during a 2025 appearance on NPR’s “Wild Card with Rachel Martin,” the 83-year-old actor spoke about what the relationship taught him.
“Old people can love, too," he said.

“You know, you think about falling in love and all of that business,” Ford continued. “You think it’s the business of youth or something, you know, and staying in love is the issue. Maintaining, nurturing, basically, not f---ing up.”
And as their 23-year relationship illustrates, there’s potential for it to last, too.
Read on to learn more about their enduring bond.
From 1st Meeting to 1st Date
Ford and Flockhart met on Jan. 20, 2002, at the Golden Globe Awards, where he received the Cecil B. DeMille Award and she was nominated for her role in “Ally McBeal.”
At the time of that first meeting, Ford was separated from his second wife, screenwriter Melissa Mathison.
Later that same year, the couple went on their first date, and they had a chaperone with them, in the form of Flockhart’s “Ally McBeal” pal James Marsden.
“I’m a harbinger of a wonderful, long relationship,” Marsden joked during an appearance on “The Late Late Show.” “I take the credit for that.”
They Married in 2010
On June 15, 2010, after eight years together, Ford and Flockhart swapped vows in a ceremony held at the Governor’s Mansion in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
They Share a Son, Liam
One year before Flockhart and Ford got together, she adopted a baby boy named Liam. Once the pair wed, Ford adopted Liam as well.

In 2008, Reader’s Digest asked Ford what sort of mother Flockhart was, to which he replied, “The best in the world. She’s a mother by choice — she adopted Liam before we met, as a single parent, which is an awesome responsibility to take. She’s devoted herself to Liam and has done a really wonderful job raising him. I’m happy to now have a part of the job.”

The actor also has four children from previous relationships, including sons Ben and Willard Ford, whom he had with first wife Mary Marquardt, as well as son Malcolm and daughter Georgia Ford, whom he shares with ex Mathison.
A Passion for Flying

Acting is what Ford is best known for, but in his off hours, he pursues his other great passion — piloting aircraft. Early in his relationship with Flockhart, he told People that it was a pursuit that brought them closer together.

“Calista loves to fly, and I’m thrilled because it’s so important to me, and it’s the kind of thing that’s so much more fun with somebody who really enjoys it,” he said in 2003. “Calista likes the process, she likes what she sees from the air, she likes seeing me. I think a lot of it has to do with that she loves to see me doing something that I love.”

While Flockhart always supported Ford’s love of flying, she became less enthusiastic about his fondness for vintage aircraft following a 2015 accident, in which he crash-landed a World War II training plane on a California golf course.
It was a wake-up call for him and Flockhart.

“I changed a lot of things in my life,” he once told the Hollywood Reporter. “My wife does not fly with me in vintage airplanes anymore — she will in others. I certainly don’t want to have to recover from that kind of accident again. It was really hard on my family, and it was hard on me.”
They Might Not Ever Work Together
They’re both Golden Globe winning actors with impressive resumes, but if fans of Ford and Flockhart are waiting to see the couple appear onscreen together, they shouldn’t get their hopes up.
While Ford has expressed interest in the idea, he worries their real-life love might keep audiences from buying any fictional arrangement.

“That kind of casting might not be the best way to bring people into an imagined situation, because (audiences) may say, ‘Oh, I know they’re married; now I’m not even thinking about the movie anymore,’” the star told Variety in 2025.
He stipulated that if he and his wife ever shared a screen, “We’d want it to be someone else’s idea,” rather than anything they pushed for themselves.
She Encourages Him to Clean Up His Act
Ford has a reputation for having a no-nonsense delivery offscreen. Some might even call him gruff, at times. He’s certainly known for using colorful language.
But in a 2023 interview with Esquire, the actor noted that Flockhart is trying to put a stop to his frequent stream of F-bombs.

“F-----‘ A,” Ford muttered during his chat with magazine. With a grin, he added, “Hey, if you don’t mind, leave the ‘f-----’ A’ out. My wife is still giving me s--- about that Hollywood Reporter thing, and I’m trying not to say that too much.”
As for the “Hollywood Reporter thing,” the “Star Wars” legend was referring to an earlier interview with the publication, one that boasted the headline, “I Know Who the F*** I Am.”
They Let Their Love Show
When it comes to the topic of his marriage to Flockhart, Ford is downright tender.
“I, like everybody else, just like everybody else, I love being in love,” Ford explained during an appearance on NPR’s “Wild Card with Rachel Martin.”
That was evident when the actor took the stage at the 2024 Critics Choice Awards to accept his Lifetime Achievement Award.
With tears in his eyes, he said, “I want to thank my lovely wife, Calista Flockhart, who supports me when I need a lot of support.”
Flockhart looked equally emotional as he added, “And I need a lot of support.”

title: Is There a New Episode of 'Dateline' On Tonight, September 12?

title: All About Sam Rockwell and Leslie Bibb’s Relationship
summary: Are Sam Rockwell and Leslie Bibb husband and wife? Here's their relationship timeline and why they decided not to get married.
story: Sam Rockwell and Leslie Bibb are the epitome of low-key Hollywood love.
They’re the opposite of flashy. They don’t grab headlines with breakups or makeups. And they certainly aren’t the talk of any tabloids.
Instead, Rockwell, 56, and Bibb, 51, have enjoyed a quiet and enduring romance for 18 years.
Read on to learn all about the stars’ long partnership.
2007: How It All Began
The actors met each other in the lobby of West Hollywood’s Chateau Marmont hotel in October 2007, where Rockwell was living as he filmed "Frost/Nixon" and Bibb was meeting friends.
Bibb spoke their origins during a 2012 interview with Rosie O’Donnell. “I just smiled and he smiled at me and I go, ‘Oh no, what’s that?’ Sometimes you just get struck,” she said.

Just one week after their first greeting, Rockwell took Bibb out for a “day date” at the Getty Museum in Los Angeles. But what Bibb didn’t know was that Rockwell had another date lined up with someone else that evening.

“I had a plan B, yeah,” he admitted during a 2025 visit to TODAY with Jenna & Friends. “(Leslie) wanted to continue on into the night, because the day date went really well. ... So, I had to kind of figure out what to do.”
What he did was cancel that second date, thus kicking off a whirlwind romance. Bibb told O’Donnell that three weeks after that museum outing, she’d already told Rockwell, “I love you so much.”
2008: Red Carpet Official

While the couple didn’t announce their relationship when it first began, they made their status clear to fans in June of 2008, when they appeared together on the red carpet for the CineVegas International Film Festival at Planet Hollywood and Casino in Las Vegas.
It was the first of many red-carpet strolls for the pair as they often show up to support each other at premieres and awards ceremonies.
2010: Taking Their Chemistry to the Screen
In 2010, Rockwell and Bibb decided they wouldn’t just keep their chemistry to themselves. Instead, the pair teamed up onscreen in “Iron Man 2.”
They must have enjoyed the collaboration as much as viewers did, because it was far from the last time their shared a screen.
That same year, the appeared in the short film “F--k,” and co-starred in another short, “The Dark of Night,” in 2017. They also starred in the 2015 comedy film “Don Verdean.”
In 2020, amid the pandemic, Rockwell and Bibb joined the cast of “Home Movie: The Princess Bride,” a streaming miniseries that recreated the 1987 classic film.
That co-working trend continued in 2025, when Rockwell made an impactful guest appearance on the third season of Bibb's series “White Lotus." He earned an Emmy nomination for that.
2018: An Oscar and a Sweet Mention

Rockwell earned an Oscar for his supporting role in the crime drama “Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri” at the 90th Academy Awards. But when he took the stage, it was clear that he was thankful for much more than the golden statuette in his hands.
After listing off the names of the co-stars and colleagues he was grateful for, Rockwell faced Bibb in the audience and added, “My beloved Leslie Bibb, you light my fire, baby. I love you.”
2020: Building a (Fur) Family Together
In February 2020, Rockwell and Bibb adopted a rescue dog together, a German Shepherd named Gus.
Gus was actually the second dog to enter their household. Bibb had another pooch, named Sadie, since before her days dating Rockwell. Sadly, Sadie passed away shortly after Gus joined the family.
As for starting a human family, Bibb has stated that she has no interest in it.
“I just don’t have that (motherhood) chip in me,” she once told TODAY’s Jenna Bush Hager. “I love dogs.”
2025: They Open Up About Not Being Married
During that same visit to TODAY, Bibb addressed whether or not she would ever consider swapping vows with her partner of 18 years.
“Listen, I love Sam Rockwell,” she insisted. “I would put him in my pocket and carry him with me all the time. I love him. I do not want to get married.”
Why? First, she explained that she already feels as if they are married. Then she added that saying “I do” simply isn’t needed.
“If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it,” Bibb put it bluntly.
Back in 2022, Rockwell shared similar sentiments about the topic, telling The Standard, “She’s in my will. I feel like we are married. We live like a married couple. I’m really proud of her.”

title: Savannah Guthrie Joins the Bob Club! Check Out Her Shorter Hairstyle
summary: Savannah Guthrie got a bob haircut from Chris McMillan, the hairstylist who previously gave one to Jenna Bush Hager live on TODAY.
story: TODAY viewers may have noticed Savannah Guthrie is looking a bit different. That’s because the TODAY co-anchor got a bob haircut.
“of course I did ✂️” she captioned an Instagram video of herself smiling and laughing along with hairstylist Chris McMillan, which she posted on Sept. 12.
“I did a thing w/mrchrismcmillan,” she wrote on the clip.
Fans loved the new look.
“So good!” one person wrote.
“Beautiful 😘❤️” another person raved.
“Pretty! Love it,” someone else commented.
It was all part of a busy day for McMillan, who appeared on TODAY earlier in the week to give two viewers bobs of their own.

“4 haircuts before 9am and the MOST FUN morning with @jennaandfriends and everyone at the @todayshow✂️ thank you so much for having me and can’t wait to share more!” he captioned an Instagram post on Sept. 11 that featured a few photos and videos of him with Savannah and Jenna Bush Hager.

The bob is having a major TODAY moment. In addition to yesterday’s work, McMillan, who famously created “The Rachel,”which was Jennifer Aniston’s iconic hairstyle on “Friends,” also gave a bob haircut to Jenna in June, live on air.
“Bobs are like spring cleaning,” he said as they got ready to do the cut. “There’s sometimes some bad damage, bad layers. It sort of evens it up.”
After her grand reveal on the show, Jenna shared in July whether she plans to keep the bob around.
“Am I keeping the bob? As of now, there’s no way not to keep the bob because it won’t grow that fast. But I do like it. I like it a lot more than I thought I would,” Jenna told TODAY.com at the time.
And the proof is on TODAY, as Jenna is still seen rocking the shorter locks.
